Executive Summary

 

Glasgow Waste Water Treatment Plant

 

? Background

Glasgow Water Company, located in Glasgow, Kentucky, operates the Glasgow 

Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP).  The facility is subject to EPA?s Risk 

Management Program in accordance with Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA).  

The WWTP treats municipal and industrial wastes prior to disposal to Huggins 

Branch.

 

? Chemical Management Program

As a concerned member of the community, the Glasgow Water Company takes its 

role as a responsible citizen very seriously.  Glasgow Water Company facilities are 

operated to protect employees, contractors and the public from injury and illness, and 

to minimize environmental impact.  Glasgow Water Company?s policy is to inspect, 

maintain and operate equipment and facilities to prevent accidents, including release 

of hazardous materials, and to train employees in prevention of accidents.

 

Glasgow Water Company has developed and implemented Process Safety 

Management (PSM) plans at each operations facility as part of an overall chemical 

management program.  The program involves the Superintendents at each facility 

along with the plant operators.

 

1) Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

 

The Glasgow WWTP has developed a PSM plan as part of the overall chemical 

management program.  The program involves the Superintendent and all operators at 

the facility.  WWTP personnel also provides safety training to staff as part of the 

accidental release prevention program.

 

2) Description of Facility and the Regulated Substances

 

The Glasgow WWTP is located at 705 Glen Garry Road in Glasgow, Kentucky.  This 

facility began operation in 1960 and is located south of the Glasgow Landfill.  The 

WWTP?s chlorination process is covered by EPA?s 40 CFR Part 68.

 

The facility operates a water treatment plant (WTP) with a maximum capacity of four 

million gallons per day (MGD). After treatment, the

waste water is discharged to 

Huggins Branch.  

 

Chlorine gas is injected into the water for disinfection purposes.  The chlorine system 

utilizes a Wallace & Tiernan vacuum operated, automatic switchover gaseous feed 

systems with two 1-ton containers piped together to provide uninterrupted flow of 

chlorine.  Currently, the feed rate for chlorine ranges from approximately 30 ? 100 

pounds per day.

 

The maximum chlorine inventory at the WWTP includes three 1-ton chlorine 

containers.  Under normal circumstances, a full container and a container in use are 

piped together and situated on the scale apparatus and a third 1-ton container is stored 

in an adjacent room separated by steel sliding doors that are kept closed unless 

employees are in the Scale Room.

 

3) Worst-Case Release Scenarios

The predicted worst-case release scenario for chlorine is a catastrophic release of one 

(full) chlorine container within the Scale Room.  This enclosure will limit the 

dispersion of both liquid and vapor to the atmosphere during a release.  For this 

scenario, 2,000 pounds of chlorine liquefied under pressure are assumed to be 

released in 10 minutes.  Using RMP*Comp Version 1.06 air dispersion modeling 

software, the distance to a toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l is predicted to be 0.9 miles.  

 

As an input parameter for RMP*Comp, the topography surrounding the WWTP was 

considered ?urban?.  It should be noted that this parameter is not directly correlated to 

population density.  Rather, the topography surrounding the facility is characterized 

as either having many obstructions ? ?urban? or generally flat with few obstructions ? 

?rural?.  It was determined that because the WWTP was surrounded by trees and 

rolling hills, the topography would be characterized as ?urban? for modeling 

purposes.

 

This 0.9 mile radius encompasses approximately 259 residences, and several 

industries.  Assuming a population multiplier of 3.5 people per residenc

e, this radius 

encompasses approximately 910 people.  The number of residences and other public 

and environmental receptors associated with this radius was provided by Glasgow 

Water Company personnel from GIS data using the latitude and longitude of the 

facility and a radius of 0.9 miles provided by EMPE.

 

4) Alternative Release Scenarios

The proposed alternative release scenario for this facility is the rupture of a 3/8 inch 

diameter flexible metal connector that conveys chlorine gas under pressure from the 

ton container to the piping manifold.  As a result, a rupture of this line would result in 

an unmitigated discharge of chlorine vapor from the container.

 

For this release scenario, the delivery line is ruptured or severed and chlorine vapor 

discharges from the end of the line at a pressure equal to that of the container.  It is 

assumed that the release occurs when the temperature of the container is 77 degrees F 

at a pressure is 113 pounds per square inch (psi).

 

Given a hole diameter of 0.11 inches at this temperature and pressure, RMP*Comp 

calculated a release rate of 20.9 pounds of chlorine per minute.  The release will 

proceed at this rate for 1 hour, at which time the release is stopped by local 

emergency responders. 

 

Off-site consequences analysis using RMP*Comp resulted in a radius of impact of 

0.1 miles.  Using the methodology described in the worst-case scenario above, it was 

determined that there are no environmental or public receptors located within this 

radius.

 

Because the specific gravity of chlorine is 2.49 (air = 1.29), chlorine vapor is more 

dense than air.  As a result, chlorine vapor may collect and/or migrate along low-lying 

areas such as the Huggins Branch, to the southeast of the facility.  However, the 

migration of chlorine vapor in the event of an actual release will be highly dependent 

upon the atmospheric conditions and release scenario at that time of the release.

 

5) Genera

l Accident Release Prevention Program

The Glasgow WWTP maintains a Process Safety Management (PSM) of Highly 

Hazardous Chemicals plan prepared in accordance with the Occupational Health and 

Safety Administration (OSHA) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  The WWTP also 

utilizes preventative maintenance programs for its system components.  The 

preventative maintenance program for the chlorination system is conducted in 

conformance with manufacturer?s recommendations.

 

6) Five-Year Accident History

Mr. Larry Estes, Glasgow WWTP Superintendent, indicated there has not been a 

reportable accident within the last five years.

 

7) Emergency Response Program

The Glasgow WWTP has implemented an Emergency Action Plan in accordance 

with OSHA PSM regulations.  The facilities will rely on the Glasgow Fire 

Department to respond in the event of a hazardous material release, fire or other 

emergency situation.  The written Emergency Action Plan contains specific 

information regarding evacuation and notification procedures in the event of a 

catastrophic chlorine release.

 

The Glasgow Fire Department has conducted a reconnaissance of the facility and 

trained personnel are ready to respond if requested.

 

8) Planned Changes to Improve Safety

 

The Glasgow WWTP is in the process of implementing safety improvements as 

recommended in the Process Safety Management program.  The improvements 

have been completed.
